title: HTML A-to-Z: The Complete Guide to HyperText Markup Language
excerpt: Master HTML from basic document structure to advanced semantic elements, forms, multimedia, accessibility, and modern best practices. A complete developer-focused guide with practical code examples.

author.name: Muhammad Usman
author.bio: Full-stack developer and technical writer specializing in modern web technologies and standards-based development.
author.title: Web Developer & Technical Author

introduction.text: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) is the foundation of every website on the internet. It structures content using elements, tags, and attributes. This guide covers HTML from A to Z — including document structure, semantic elements, forms, media, accessibility, tables, metadata, and modern best practices — strictly focused on HTML without CSS or JavaScript frameworks.

subsections.content: Every HTML document follows a standard structure including the doctype declaration, html root element, head metadata section, and body content area.

codeSnippets.title: Basic HTML Template
codeSnippets.code:
Hello World

This is a basic HTML document.

subsections.content: HTML elements define structure, while attributes provide additional information such as links, identifiers, or metadata.

codeSnippets.title: Element with Attributes
codeSnippets.code: Visit Website

subsections.content: HTML provides six heading levels and paragraph elements to structure textual content hierarchically.

codeSnippets.title: Headings Example
codeSnippets.code:
Main Heading

Sub Heading

This is a paragraph of text.

subsections.content: Lists can be ordered, unordered, or definition-based.

codeSnippets.title: Unordered and Ordered Lists
codeSnippets.code:
• HTML
  • CSS
  1. Step One
  2. Step Two

subsections.content: Anchor tags create hyperlinks to other pages, files, email addresses, or internal sections.

codeSnippets.title: Internal and External Links
codeSnippets.code: About Us Google

subsections.content: Images are embedded using the img element with required src and alt attributes.

codeSnippets.title: Image Example

subsections.content: HTML5 provides native support for embedding audio and video files.

codeSnippets.title: Video Example
codeSnippets.code:
<video controls>
  <source src="movie.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  Your browser does not support video.
</video>

subsections.content: Tables organize data into rows and columns using table, tr, th, and td elements.

codeSnippets.title: Basic Table
codeSnippets.code:
Name Age
Ali 25

subsections.content: Forms collect user input and send data to a server using various input types.

codeSnippets.title: Simple Form
codeSnippets.code:
<form action="/submit" method="POST">
  <label for="name">Name:</label>
  <input type="text" id="name" name="name" required>
  <button type="submit">Submit</button>
</form>

subsections.content: HTML supports specialized input types for better user experience.

codeSnippets.title: Advanced Inputs
codeSnippets.code:
<input type="email">
<input type="date">
<input type="color">
<input type="range" min="0" max="100">

subsections.content: Semantic elements clearly describe their meaning to browsers and developers.

codeSnippets.title: Semantic Layout Example
codeSnippets.code:
Website Title

Article Heading

Article content...

© 2026

subsections.content: Meta tags provide information about the page to search engines and browsers.

codeSnippets.title: SEO Meta Tags
codeSnippets.code:
<meta name="description" content="Complete HTML Guide">
<meta name="keywords" content="HTML, Web Development">
<meta name="author" content="Muhammad Usman">

subsections.content: Accessible HTML ensures content is usable by screen readers and assistive technologies.

codeSnippets.title: Accessible Button
codeSnippets.code: <button aria-label="Close Menu">X</button>

conclusion.text: HTML is the structural backbone of the web. Mastering it means understanding document structure, semantic elements, accessibility, forms, tables, metadata, and multimedia. While technologies evolve, HTML remains the universal language of web content. A strong HTML foundation ensures clean, accessible, and future-proof web development.

newsletter.ctaText: Get weekly web development tutorials and HTML deep dives delivered to your inbox.

title: CSS A-to-Z: The Complete Guide to Cascading Style Sheets
excerpt: Master CSS from basic styling to advanced layouts, animations, responsive design, and modern best practices. A complete developer-focused guide with practical code examples.

author.name: Muhammad Usman
author.bio: Full-stack developer and technical writer specializing in modern web technologies and standards-based development.
author.title: Web Developer & Technical Author

introduction.text: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is the styling language that brings visual design to the web. It controls layout, colors, fonts, animations, and responsive behavior. This guide covers CSS from A to Z — including selectors, box model, flexbox, grid, animations, transitions, responsive design, and modern best practices — strictly focused on CSS fundamentals and advanced techniques.

subsections.content: CSS uses selectors to target HTML elements and apply styles through property-value pairs.

codeSnippets.title: Basic CSS Syntax

subsections.content: Every element in CSS is a box with content, padding, border, and margin areas.

codeSnippets.title: Box Model Example

subsections.content: CSS supports various color formats including named colors, hex, RGB, and HSL.

codeSnippets.title: Color Examples

subsections.content: Control text appearance with font properties, line height, and text styling.

codeSnippets.title: Typography Styling

subsections.content: Flexbox is a one-dimensional layout method for arranging items in rows or columns.

codeSnippets.title: Flexbox Container

subsections.content: Grid is a two-dimensional layout system for creating complex responsive layouts.

codeSnippets.title: Grid Layout

subsections.content: Media queries allow styles to adapt based on screen size and device characteristics.

codeSnippets.title: Responsive Breakpoints

subsections.content: Transitions create smooth changes between property values.

codeSnippets.title: Transition Example

subsections.content: Animations define keyframes for complex motion and effects.

codeSnippets.title: Keyframe Animation

subsections.content: Advanced selectors target specific states and parts of elements.

codeSnippets.title: Advanced Selectors

subsections.content: CSS variables allow reusable values throughout stylesheets.

codeSnippets.title: Using CSS Variables

subsections.content: CSS positioning controls element placement with static, relative, absolute, fixed, and sticky values.

codeSnippets.title: Positioning Example

subsections.content: Modern CSS includes container queries, clamp(), and advanced viewport units.

codeSnippets.title: Modern CSS

conclusion.text: CSS is the visual backbone of the web. Mastering it means understanding selectors, the box model, layout systems, responsive design, animations, and modern features. While trends change, CSS fundamentals remain essential. A strong CSS foundation ensures beautiful, responsive, and maintainable web designs.

newsletter.ctaText: Get weekly web development tutorials and CSS deep dives delivered to your inbox.

title: JavaScript A-to-Z: The Complete Guide to Modern JavaScript
excerpt: Master JavaScript from basic syntax to advanced concepts including ES6+, async programming, DOM manipulation, and modern best practices. A complete developer-focused guide with practical code examples.

author.name: Muhammad Usman
author.bio: Full-stack developer and technical writer specializing in modern web technologies and standards-based development.
author.title: Web Developer & Technical Author

introduction.text: JavaScript is the programming language of the web, enabling interactive and dynamic user experiences. It runs in browsers and on servers via Node.js. This guide covers JavaScript from A to Z — including variables, functions, objects, arrays, async programming, DOM manipulation, ES6+ features, and modern best practices — strictly focused on JavaScript fundamentals and advanced concepts.

subsections.content: JavaScript uses let, const, and var to declare variables with different scoping rules and supports primitive and reference data types.

codeSnippets.title: Variable Declaration

subsections.content: JavaScript provides arithmetic, comparison, logical, and assignment operators for manipulating values.

codeSnippets.title: Common Operators

subsections.content: Functions are reusable blocks of code that can be declared or expressed.

codeSnippets.title: Function Types

subsections.content: Functions that take other functions as arguments or return functions.

codeSnippets.title: Array Methods

subsections.content: Objects store collections of key-value pairs and can be created and manipulated in various ways.

codeSnippets.title: Object Operations

subsections.content: Arrays are ordered collections with powerful built-in methods.

codeSnippets.title: Array Methods

subsections.content: Promises represent eventual completion or failure of asynchronous operations.

codeSnippets.title: Promise Example

subsections.content: Async/await syntax provides cleaner asynchronous code handling.

codeSnippets.title: Async/Await

subsections.content: JavaScript can interact with HTML elements through the Document Object Model.

codeSnippets.title: DOM Operations

subsections.content: Events allow JavaScript to respond to user interactions.

codeSnippets.title: Event Listeners

subsections.content: Modern JavaScript features improve code readability and efficiency.

codeSnippets.title: ES6 Syntax

subsections.content: Classes provide a cleaner syntax for object-oriented programming in JavaScript.

codeSnippets.title: Class Example

subsections.content: Error handling prevents crashes and provides graceful error recovery.

codeSnippets.title: Error Handling

subsections.content: Modules allow code organization and reusability across files.

codeSnippets.title: Import/Export

conclusion.text: JavaScript is the dynamic backbone of modern web development. Mastering it means understanding variables, functions, objects, asynchronous programming, DOM manipulation, and ES6+ features. While frameworks come and go, JavaScript fundamentals remain essential. A strong JavaScript foundation ensures powerful, interactive, and maintainable web applications.

newsletter.ctaText: Get weekly web development tutorials and JavaScript deep dives delivered to your inbox.

title: Python A-to-Z: The Complete Guide to Python Programming
excerpt: Master Python from basic syntax to advanced concepts including data structures, OOP, file handling, libraries, and modern best practices. A complete developer-focused guide with practical code examples.

author.name: Muhammad Usman
author.bio: Full-stack developer and technical writer specializing in modern web technologies and standards-based development.
author.title: Web Developer & Technical Author

introduction.text: Python is a versatile, high-level programming language known for its simplicity and readability. It's used in web development, data science, automation, AI, and more. This guide covers Python from A to Z — including syntax, data structures, functions, OOP, file handling, libraries, and modern best practices — strictly focused on Python fundamentals and advanced programming concepts.

subsections.content: Python is dynamically typed and supports various data types including integers, floats, strings, and booleans.

codeSnippets.title: Basic Variables
codeSnippets.code:
# Variable assignments
name = 'Alice'
age = 30
height = 5.7
is_student = False

# Multiple assignment
x, y, z = 1, 2, 3

# Type checking
print(type(name))  # <class 'str'>

subsections.content: Python provides arithmetic, comparison, logical, and assignment operators.

codeSnippets.title: Python Operators
codeSnippets.code:
# Arithmetic
sum_val = 10 + 5
power = 2 ** 3

# Comparison
is_equal = (10 == 10)

# Logical
result = True and False

# Membership
list_check = 5 in [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

subsections.content: Python uses if, elif, and else for conditional execution.

codeSnippets.title: If-Else Example

subsections.content: Python supports for and while loops for iteration.

codeSnippets.title: Loop Examples
codeSnippets.code:
# For loop
for i in range(5):
    print(i)

# While loop
count = 0
while count < 5:
    print(count)
    count += 1

# List comprehension
squares = [x**2 for x in range(10)]

subsections.content: Lists are mutable ordered collections, while tuples are immutable.

codeSnippets.title: Lists and Tuples
codeSnippets.code:
# Lists
fruits = ['apple', 'banana', 'orange']
fruits.append('grape')
fruits[0] = 'mango'

# Tuples
coordinates = (10, 20)
# coordinates[0] = 15  # Error: tuples are immutable

subsections.content: Dictionaries store key-value pairs, sets store unique unordered elements.

codeSnippets.title: Dictionaries and Sets

subsections.content: Functions are reusable blocks of code defined with the def keyword.

codeSnippets.title: Function Examples
codeSnippets.code:
# Basic function
def greet(name):
    return f'Hello, {name}!'

# Default parameters
def power(base, exp=2):
    return base ** exp

# Lambda function
square = lambda x: x ** 2

subsections.content: Python supports *args, **kwargs, and decorators for advanced function usage.

codeSnippets.title: Advanced Functions

subsections.content: Python supports OOP with classes, inheritance, and encapsulation.

codeSnippets.title: Class Example

subsections.content: Classes can inherit from other classes to reuse and extend functionality.

codeSnippets.title: Inheritance Example

subsections.content: Python provides simple methods to read from and write to files.

codeSnippets.title: File Operations
codeSnippets.code:
# Writing to file
with open('data.txt', 'w') as file:
    file.write('Hello, World!')

# Reading from file
with open('data.txt', 'r') as file:
    content = file.read()
    print(content)

# Reading lines
with open('data.txt', 'r') as file:
    lines = file.readlines()

subsections.content: Handle errors gracefully using try-except blocks.

codeSnippets.title: Error Handling

subsections.content: Organize code into modules and import functionality as needed.

codeSnippets.title: Module Import
codeSnippets.code:
# Import entire module
import math
print(math.pi)

# Import specific function
from datetime import datetime
print(datetime.now())

# Import with alias
import numpy as np

subsections.content: Python has rich ecosystem of libraries for various tasks.

codeSnippets.title: Library Examples
codeSnippets.code:
# NumPy for numerical computing
import numpy as np
array = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4])

# Pandas for data analysis
import pandas as pd
df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, 2], 'B': [3, 4]})

# Requests for HTTP
import requests
response = requests.get('https://api.example.com')

conclusion.text: Python is a powerful and versatile programming language. Mastering it means understanding syntax, data structures, OOP, file handling, and its extensive library ecosystem. While tools and frameworks evolve, Python fundamentals remain constant. A strong Python foundation enables development across web, data science, automation, and AI domains.

newsletter.ctaText: Get weekly programming tutorials and Python deep dives delivered to your inbox.

title: Java A-to-Z: The Complete Guide to Java Programming
excerpt: Master Java from basic syntax to advanced concepts including OOP, collections, multithreading, and modern best practices. A complete developer-focused guide with practical code examples.

author.name: Muhammad Usman
author.bio: Full-stack developer and technical writer specializing in modern web technologies and standards-based development.
author.title: Web Developer & Technical Author

introduction.text: Java is a powerful, object-oriented programming language known for platform independence and enterprise-level applications. It runs on the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) and follows the 'write once, run anywhere' principle. This guide covers Java from A to Z — including syntax, OOP, collections, exception handling, multithreading, and modern best practices — strictly focused on Java fundamentals and advanced programming concepts.

subsections.content: Every Java program requires a class and a main method as the entry point.

codeSnippets.title: Hello World Program

subsections.content: Java is strongly typed with primitive and reference data types.

codeSnippets.title: Variable Declaration

subsections.content: Java uses if-else, switch statements for decision making.

codeSnippets.title: If-Else and Switch

subsections.content: Java supports for, while, and do-while loops for iteration.

codeSnippets.title: Loop Examples

subsections.content: Java is fundamentally object-oriented with classes as blueprints for objects.

codeSnippets.title: Class Definition

subsections.content: Java supports inheritance for code reuse and polymorphism for flexible design.

codeSnippets.title: Inheritance Example

subsections.content: Interfaces define contracts that classes must implement.

codeSnippets.title: Interface Example

subsections.content: Abstract classes provide partial implementation and cannot be instantiated.

codeSnippets.title: Abstract Class

subsections.content: Java Collections Framework provides data structures for storing and manipulating groups of objects.

codeSnippets.title: Collections Examples

subsections.content: Java uses exceptions to handle runtime errors gracefully.

codeSnippets.title: Exception Handling

subsections.content: Java supports concurrent programming through threads.

codeSnippets.title: Thread Examples

subsections.content: Java provides multiple ways to handle file operations.

codeSnippets.title: File Operations

subsections.content: Modern Java includes functional programming features.

codeSnippets.title: Lambda and Streams

conclusion.text: Java is a robust, platform-independent programming language. Mastering it means understanding OOP principles, collections, exception handling, multithreading, and modern features. While frameworks and tools evolve, Java fundamentals remain essential. A strong Java foundation ensures scalable, maintainable, and enterprise-grade application development.

newsletter.ctaText: Get weekly programming tutorials and Java deep dives delivered to your inbox.

title: C Programming A-to-Z: The Complete Guide to C Language
excerpt: Master C from basic syntax to advanced concepts including pointers, memory management, data structures, and modern best practices. A complete developer-focused guide with practical code examples.

featuredImage.alt: C programming code displayed on screen

author.name: Muhammad Usman
author.bio: Full-stack developer and technical writer specializing in modern web technologies and standards-based development.
author.title: Web Developer & Technical Author

introduction.text: C is a powerful, low-level programming language that forms the foundation of modern computing. It provides direct hardware access, efficient memory management, and serves as the basis for operating systems and embedded systems. This guide covers C from A to Z — including syntax, pointers, memory management, file I/O, data structures, and best practices — strictly focused on C fundamentals and advanced programming concepts.

subsections.content: Every C program starts with the main function and requires preprocessor directives for libraries.

codeSnippets.title: Hello World Program

subsections.content: C supports various data types including integers, floats, characters, and custom types.

codeSnippets.title: Variable Declaration

subsections.content: C provides operators for mathematical operations, comparisons, and logical expressions.

codeSnippets.title: Operator Examples

subsections.content: C uses if-else and switch statements for decision making.

codeSnippets.title: If-Else and Switch

subsections.content: C supports for, while, and do-while loops for iteration.

codeSnippets.title: Loop Examples

subsections.content: Functions enable code reusability and modular programming in C.

codeSnippets.title: Function Examples

subsections.content: Functions can call themselves to solve problems recursively.

codeSnippets.title: Recursive Function

subsections.content: Pointers store memory addresses and enable direct memory manipulation.

codeSnippets.title: Pointer Examples

subsections.content: Pointers can be incremented and decremented to traverse memory.

codeSnippets.title: Pointer Arithmetic

subsections.content: Arrays store collections of elements of the same type.

codeSnippets.title: Array Examples

subsections.content: Strings in C are arrays of characters terminated by null character.

codeSnippets.title: String Operations

subsections.content: Structures group different data types under a single name.

codeSnippets.title: Structure Example

subsections.content: Dynamic memory allocation allows runtime memory management.

codeSnippets.title: Memory Allocation

subsections.content: C provides functions to read from and write to files.

codeSnippets.title: File Operations

conclusion.text: C is a foundational programming language that provides low-level control and high performance. Mastering it means understanding pointers, memory management, data structures, and system-level programming. While higher-level languages exist, C fundamentals remain crucial for systems programming, embedded systems, and understanding computer architecture. A strong C foundation enables efficient and powerful software development.

newsletter.ctaText: Get weekly programming tutorials and C language deep dives delivered to your inbox.

title: PHP A-to-Z: The Complete Guide to PHP Programming
excerpt: Master PHP from basic syntax to advanced concepts including OOP, databases, security, and modern best practices. A complete developer-focused guide with practical code examples.

author.name: Muhammad Usman
author.bio: Full-stack developer and technical writer specializing in modern web technologies and standards-based development.
author.title: Web Developer & Technical Author

introduction.text: PHP (Hypertext Preprocessor) is a server-side scripting language widely used for web development. It powers major platforms like WordPress, Facebook, and Wikipedia. This guide covers PHP from A to Z — including syntax, variables, functions, OOP, database interaction, security, and modern best practices — strictly focused on PHP fundamentals and advanced server-side programming concepts.

subsections.content: PHP code is executed on the server and embedded within HTML using special tags.

codeSnippets.title: Hello World in PHP
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
// Single line comment

/* Multi-line
   comment */

echo "Hello, World!";
print "PHP is awesome!";

// Variables
$name = "Alice";
$age = 25;

echo "My name is $name and I am $age years old.";
?>

subsections.content: PHP is loosely typed and supports various data types.

codeSnippets.title: Data Types
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
// String
$name = "John";

// Integer
$age = 30;

// Float
$price = 99.99;

// Boolean
$isActive = true;

// Array
$colors = array("red", "green", "blue");

// Null
$value = null;

// Check type
var_dump($age);
?>

subsections.content: PHP supports arithmetic, comparison, logical, and assignment operators.

codeSnippets.title: PHP Operators
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
// Arithmetic
$sum = 10 + 5;
$product = 10 * 5;

// Comparison
$isEqual = (10 == 10);
$isIdentical = (10 === "10");  // false

// Logical
$result = (true && false);

// String concatenation
$fullName = "John" . " " . "Doe";

// Ternary
$status = ($age >= 18) ? "Adult" : "Minor";
?>

subsections.content: PHP uses if-else and switch for decision making.

codeSnippets.title: Control Structures
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
$score = 85;

// If-else
if ($score >= 90) {
    echo "Grade: A";
} elseif ($score >= 80) {
    echo "Grade: B";
} else {
    echo "Grade: C";
}

// Switch
$day = "Monday";
switch ($day) {
    case "Monday":
        echo "Start of week";
        break;
    case "Friday":
        echo "End of week";
        break;
    default:
        echo "Midweek";
}
?>

subsections.content: PHP supports for, while, do-while, and foreach loops.

codeSnippets.title: Loop Examples
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
// For loop
for ($i = 0; $i < 5; $i++) {
    echo $i . " ";
}

// While loop
$count = 0;
while ($count < 5) {
    echo $count . " ";
    $count++;
}

// Foreach loop
$colors = array("red", "green", "blue");
foreach ($colors as $color) {
    echo $color . " ";
}

// Foreach with key-value
$person = array("name" => "John", "age" => 30);
foreach ($person as $key => $value) {
    echo "$key: $value\n";
}
?>

subsections.content: Functions encapsulate reusable code blocks in PHP.

codeSnippets.title: Function Examples
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
// Basic function
function greet($name) {
    return "Hello, $name!";
}

echo greet("Alice");

// Default parameters
function power($base, $exp = 2) {
    return pow($base, $exp);
}

echo power(3);  // 9
echo power(3, 3);  // 27

// Variable scope
$global_var = "I'm global";

function testScope() {
    global $global_var;
    echo $global_var;
}
?>

subsections.content: PHP supports anonymous functions (closures) for flexible programming.

codeSnippets.title: Anonymous Functions
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
// Anonymous function
$multiply = function($a, $b) {
    return $a * $b;
};

echo $multiply(5, 3);

// Using with array_map
$numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
$squared = array_map(function($n) {
    return $n * $n;
}, $numbers);

print_r($squared);
?>

subsections.content: PHP provides powerful array manipulation functions.

codeSnippets.title: Working with Arrays
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
// Indexed array
$fruits = array("apple", "banana", "orange");
$fruits[] = "grape";  // Add element

// Associative array
$person = array(
    "name" => "John",
    "age" => 30,
    "city" => "NYC"
);

// Array functions
array_push($fruits, "mango");
array_pop($fruits);
$count = count($fruits);
$exists = in_array("apple", $fruits);

// Multidimensional array
$matrix = array(
    array(1, 2, 3),
    array(4, 5, 6)
);
?>

subsections.content: PHP supports OOP with classes, inheritance, and encapsulation.

codeSnippets.title: Class Definition
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
class Person {
    // Properties
    private $name;
    private $age;
    
    // Constructor
    public function __construct($name, $age) {
        $this->name = $name;
        $this->age = $age;
    }
    
    // Methods
    public function introduce() {
        return "I'm {$this->name}, {$this->age} years old.";
    }
    
    // Getter
    public function getName() {
        return $this->name;
    }
}

// Create object
$person = new Person("Alice", 25);
echo $person->introduce();
?>

subsections.content: PHP supports inheritance and interfaces for flexible design.

codeSnippets.title: Inheritance Example
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
class Animal {
    protected $name;
    
    public function __construct($name) {
        $this->name = $name;
    }
    
    public function makeSound() {
        return "Some sound";
    }
}

class Dog extends Animal {
    public function makeSound() {
        return "{$this->name} barks!";
    }
}

// Interface
interface Drawable {
    public function draw();
}

class Circle implements Drawable {
    public function draw() {
        return "Drawing circle";
    }
}
?>

subsections.content: PHP interacts with databases using MySQLi or PDO.

codeSnippets.title: Database Connection (PDO)
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
try {
    // Connect to database
    $pdo = new PDO(
        'mysql:host=localhost;dbname=mydb',
        'username',
        'password'
    );
    $pdo->setAttribute(PDO::ATTR_ERRMODE, PDO::ERRMODE_EXCEPTION);
    
    // Prepared statement (prevents SQL injection)
    $stmt = $pdo->prepare("SELECT * FROM users WHERE email = :email");
    $stmt->execute(['email' => $email]);
    $user = $stmt->fetch(PDO::FETCH_ASSOC);
    
    // Insert data
    $stmt = $pdo->prepare("INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES (:name, :email)");
    $stmt->execute([
        'name' => 'John',
        'email' => 'john@example.com'
    ]);
    
} catch(PDOException $e) {
    echo "Error: " . $e->getMessage();
}
?>

subsections.content: PHP handles form data with built-in security considerations.

codeSnippets.title: Secure Form Handling
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
// Check request method
if ($_SERVER['REQUEST_METHOD'] == 'POST') {
    // Sanitize input
    $name = htmlspecialchars($_POST['name']);
    $email = filter_var($_POST['email'], FILTER_SANITIZE_EMAIL);
    
    // Validate email
    if (filter_var($email, FILTER_VALIDATE_EMAIL)) {
        echo "Valid email: $email";
    } else {
        echo "Invalid email";
    }
    
    // Prevent XSS
    $comment = htmlspecialchars($_POST['comment'], ENT_QUOTES, 'UTF-8');
    
    // CSRF protection (use token)
    if ($_POST['csrf_token'] === $_SESSION['csrf_token']) {
        // Process form
    }
}
?>

subsections.content: PHP uses sessions and cookies to maintain state across requests.

codeSnippets.title: Sessions and Cookies
codeSnippets.code:
<?php
// Start session
session_start();

// Set session variable
$_SESSION['username'] = 'john_doe';
$_SESSION['user_id'] = 123;

// Access session
if (isset($_SESSION['username'])) {
    echo "Welcome, " . $_SESSION['username'];
}

// Destroy session
session_destroy();

// Set cookie
setcookie('user', 'john', time() + 3600, '/');

// Access cookie
if (isset($_COOKIE['user'])) {
    echo "User: " . $_COOKIE['user'];
}
?>

conclusion.text: PHP is a versatile server-side scripting language powering millions of websites. Mastering it means understanding syntax, OOP, database interaction, security practices, and modern development patterns. While frameworks like Laravel and Symfony exist, PHP fundamentals remain essential. A strong PHP foundation enables building secure, scalable, and dynamic web applications.

newsletter.ctaText: Get weekly web development tutorials and PHP deep dives delivered to your inbox.

title: TypeScript A-to-Z: The Complete Guide to TypeScript
excerpt: Master TypeScript from basic syntax to advanced concepts including types, interfaces, generics, and modern best practices. A complete developer-focused guide with practical code examples.

author.name: Muhammad Usman
author.bio: Full-stack developer and technical writer specializing in modern web technologies and standards-based development.
author.title: Web Developer & Technical Author

introduction.text: TypeScript is a strongly-typed superset of JavaScript that compiles to plain JavaScript. It adds static type checking, interfaces, and modern features to enhance code quality and developer experience. This guide covers TypeScript from A to Z — including types, interfaces, generics, decorators, and modern best practices — strictly focused on TypeScript fundamentals and advanced type system concepts.

subsections.content: TypeScript provides static type checking with built-in primitive and complex types.

codeSnippets.title: Basic Type Annotations

subsections.content: TypeScript can automatically infer types based on initial values.

codeSnippets.title: Type Inference

subsections.content: Interfaces define contracts for object shapes and can be extended.

codeSnippets.title: Interface Examples

subsections.content: Type aliases create custom type names for any type combination.

codeSnippets.title: Type Alias Examples

subsections.content: TypeScript provides strong typing for function parameters and return values.

codeSnippets.title: Typed Functions

subsections.content: TypeScript enhances JavaScript classes with access modifiers and type safety.

codeSnippets.title: Class Example

subsections.content: TypeScript supports class inheritance and abstract classes for polymorphism.

codeSnippets.title: Inheritance

subsections.content: Generics enable writing reusable, type-safe code that works with multiple types.

codeSnippets.title: Generic Examples

subsections.content: Combine types using union (|) and intersection (&) operators.

codeSnippets.title: Advanced Type Operations

subsections.content: TypeScript provides built-in utility types for type transformations.

codeSnippets.title: Utility Types

subsections.content: TypeScript uses ES6 module syntax with enhanced type support.

codeSnippets.title: Module System

subsections.content: Decorators add metadata and modify class behavior (experimental feature).

codeSnippets.title: Decorator Examples

subsections.content: Configure TypeScript compiler options for your project.

codeSnippets.title: TypeScript Configuration
codeSnippets.code:
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ES2020",
    "module": "commonjs",
    "lib": ["ES2020"],
    "outDir": "./dist",
    "rootDir": "./src",
    "strict": true,
    "esModuleInterop": true,
    "skipLibCheck": true,
    "forceConsistentCasingInFileNames": true,
    "resolveJsonModule": true,
    "declaration": true,
    "declarationMap": true,
    "sourceMap": true,
    "noUnusedLocals": true,
    "noUnusedParameters": true,
    "noImplicitReturns": true
  },
  "include": ["src/**/*"],
  "exclude": ["node_modules", "dist"]
}

conclusion.text: TypeScript is a powerful enhancement to JavaScript that brings type safety and modern features to web development. Mastering it means understanding types, interfaces, generics, classes, and advanced type system concepts. While JavaScript remains the runtime language, TypeScript's compile-time checks prevent bugs and improve code quality. A strong TypeScript foundation enables building scalable, maintainable, and robust applications.
